job_title: Therapist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Working with the clients is very rewarding and worthwhile. Many of the clients are in the most vulnerable populations and desperate for help and compassion. There are many dedicated staff members
cons: The work environment is incredibly stressful and often for reasons that do not make sense. Management makes things unduly stressful for clients and staff. There is a lot of prejudice that happens with clients of color that is swept under the rug. Often these problems are presented as client failings or problems instead of the systemic issues. There are a lot of unreasonable expectations for therapists related to administrative tasks and documentation within the therapy session which leave little time to do therapy with clients. Many of these tasks could be completed by case managers to allow for more consistency in therapy sessions. Management seems unaware of reality of day to day activities. There is also a lot of favoritism amongst employees including schedules, assigned tasks, and treatment of staff. The pay is also significantly lower than other organizations in the area for similar jobs.

review_title: Most organized Non-Profit I've Worked For (So Far)
job_title: Intake Coordinator
pros: -Staff Training/Growth: i have been here for less than 6 months and I have already been in several trainings, some even offer raises at the end. I have had lots of opportunity to grow as a staff member in the short time I have been here -Great Benefits: incredible health and dental and very inexpensive! Also time off is good. And there is tuition reimbursement available. -Fun Co-Workers: I love my team and my staff is easy to work with, we have a great time! -Focus on conflict resolution and interpersonal skills: because of the nature of our work, interpersonal skills and conflict resolution skills area t the core of our work. The work we do with clients absolutely translates to the work we do with our staff. -The work is important: any non-profit can say this, of course, but I am very connected to the work that we do and the clients are beautiful people I am excited to help every day. -Organized: I've worked at a LOT of non-profits, and in general they can be poor catalysts for systemic change (this is a whole other discussion), but OH, for what it is, does a good job. They are organized, care about their staff, provide us with opportunities, try to make training easier, and work with the community and with policy to try to make our job easier.
cons: -Complex: this job can be hard, complex, and emotionally draining. You need to develop healthy work life boundaries on your own before you work in this field. -Complacency with upper management: sometimes it feels like upper management is so disconnected from staff. How much money are they making vs how much we are making, who we work with everyday vs who they talk to every day. But like I said earlier, non-profits are a tricky beast, and I think the exec team tries its best to be transparent with staff about what is going on. -Pay: If you are looking for a high paying job, social work is not your area. I think staff could always stand to get paid more, and I think that with the benefits package it evens out. -Understaffing!!!!

job_title: Therapist
pros:
I love working with our clients. They have had so much trauma and difficulties in their lives. They are often longing for healthy support to give them a chance to heal. I love watching them as they start the healing process and learn new ways of living. 
I love knowing that I work for an ethical company with supervisors and directors that I truly respect. I know they have the best interests of our clients and staff in mind. 
I really enjoy the people I work with. They are compassionate and fun-loving. 
We have incentives both individual and team based. For example, completing notes on time you can earn gift cards. 
This is really a team atmosphere which gives you the opportunity to learn and grow as a professional.
We get information about trainings and CEU opportunities. We also have helpful trainings throughout the year. 
There are a variety of shifts available depending on what you prefer. There's also good health insurance, paid time off, and 2 personal days per year.
cons:
This is a tough field, and it can be really hard to watch when clients are struggling. 
There is a lot of documentation, court reports, funding requests, probation reports, etc.

job_title: Therapist
pros:
I have been able to move around the agency several times to jobs that either better suited my likes or career aspirations.
The teams I have worked on have been great to work with.
My supervisors have all wanted me to succeed and shown it.
Challenging atmosphere, regardless of skill level of therapist.
Benefits package has been pretty good.
You can get specific training paid for ie EMDR, ASAM, MI, DBT, etc.
cons:
The high family-like atmosphere is nice, but it can create expectations that are difficult to reconcile with ie. One can feel guilty for not doing more for their fellow team members if others do. This can create a difficult work/life balance expectation.
Sometimes the new hire training is brushed aside for more urgent matters or due to staffing shortages.
Working with Medicaid, one the primary payors for clients, is ridiculous. If you are good at writing, you'll be fine, but if you struggle with writing, you will struggle with the documentation that Medicaid requires.

job_title: Middle Management
pros: I've been with Odyssey for close to 4 years. Started as an intern, became a full-time therapist and then moved into middle management. There has been challenges and at times it was really hard work. But I've also never, ever worked somewhere that I felt so much appreciation and support. The staff is an amazing set of people who care deeply about our clients and work extremely hard to help people change their lives. There's no judgement, only a desire for helping others. The staff is also very dedicated to one another; it's a very supportive and encouraging environment. No one is trying to get ahead of others, and we have an amazing conflict resolution process. We are encouraged to bring things up and address them openly and it makes a huge difference in the way we interact with each other. We do team building activities that are actually fun and enjoyable - I've never had to do a trust fall, but I did get to learn how to paint, done a couple "murder-mystery" nights, and how to put together a terrarium. We celebrate successes with each other, and help each other through difficult times as well. It is a seriously challenging job at times and it's also amazing to be able to get support from my peers whenever I need it.
cons: It's a hard job, for sure. We experience the struggles of our clients and sit with them in really difficult times. We sometimes work long hours, have to have really hard conversations, have to give bad news, and we see people struggle and lose the fight with addiction. It's not an easy job and we don't always get a lot of thanks. The pay isn't super great at times, but it is a non-profit and we certainly aren't doing the job for the money.
